text: 18.01A Topic 11: Improper integrals. Read: TB: 12.4, SN: INT Deﬁnition: ∫ ∞ a f (x) dx = lim b→∞ ∫ b a f (x) dx. If the limit exits we say the improper integral converges otherwise we say it diverges. Example: Compute ∫ ∞ 1 1 xn dx. (To avoid an annoying case, assume n ̸= 1.) Improper int. = lim b→∞ x−n+1 −n + 1         b 1 = lim b→∞ b−n+1 −n + 1 + 1 n − 1 = { 1 n−1 if n > 1 ∞ if n < 1 So the integral converges if n > 1 and diverges to ∞ if n < 1. If n = 1 it also diverges to ∞. Example: (Probably don’t have time to do this in class. We did some of this before, when we worked on work.) We can do better. Limit comparison: Assume f, g are positive functions. If lim x→∞ f g = c and c ̸= 0, ∞ then both improper integrals converge or both diverge. Notes: 1. If c ̸= 0, ∞ we write f ∼ g. 2. Also called Asymptotic comparison. Example: If f = 1√x3−1 , g = 1 x3/2 then lim x→∞ f g = 1. Thus, since ∫ ∞ 2 1 x3/2 dx converges so does ∫ ∞ 2 1√x3−1 dx. Note: We need the lower limit in the integral > 1 so g(x) is deﬁned on the entire interval we integrate over. ”Proof” of limit comparison: lim f g = c ⇒ there is an a such that c 2 g(x) < f (x) < 2cg(x) for x > a. Thus c 2 ∫ ∞ a g(x) dx < ∫ ∞ a f (x) dx < 2c ∫ ∞ a g(x) dx. This shows both integrals converge or both diverge. QED Other improper integrals: Example: ∫ 1 0 1 x1/3 dx This is improper because 1 x1/3 = ∞ when x = 0. It is sometimes written as: ∫ ∞ 1 1 xp dx → { p > 1 converges p ≤ 1 diverges ∫ 1 0+ 1 xp dx → { p < 1 converges p ≥ 1 diverges Comparison works for these types of improper integrals also. Example: ∫ 1 0+ 1√x(x+1) dx converges since 1√x(x+1) ≤ 1√x Be careful –at ﬁrst glance you might think the appropriate p for comparison is p = 1.
